title: 1000th digit!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000^\\text{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digit to the right of the decimal point in the decimal representation of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1+\\sqrt{2})^{3000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's a rigorous solution to go along with Darryl Stein's nice observations."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Use the Binomial Theorem to write 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x = (1 + \sqrt{2})^{3000} = \sum_{i=0}^{3000} {3000 \choose i} \sqrt{2}^i "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Notice that the even terms in this sum are integers.
Notice that the binomial expansion of the "conjugate" expression, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = (1 - \sqrt{2})^{3000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the same thing, but with the odd terms negated:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" y = (1 - \sqrt{2})^{3000} = \sum_{i=0}^{3000} {3000 \choose i} (-\sqrt{2})^i "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Adding these formulae, the odd terms cancel, and we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x + y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a (fairly large) integer!
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x + y = 2 \sum_{i = 0}^{1500} {3000 \choose 2i} 2^i"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Put another way, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are additive inverses (mod 1).
Interestingly, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are also multiplicative inverses (over the reals), since
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (1 + \sqrt{2})(1 - \sqrt{2}) = 1 - 2 = -1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-1^{3000} = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; however, we will not need this fact."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Next we will show that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 < y < 10^{-1000} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
and hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s 1000'th digit after the decimal place is 0.  Equivalently,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 < (\sqrt{2} - 1)^3 < \frac{1}{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
which follows because "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sqrt{2} < \frac{10}{7} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \left( \frac{3}{7}\right) ^3 = \frac{27}{343} < \frac{1}{10} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally, since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are additive inverses (mod 1), and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has a 0 in its 1000'th decimal digit, 
and some nonzeros in later decimal digits, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must have a 9 in its 1000'th decimal digit.  Here we also
used the fact that both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are positive."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is an observation rather than an exact solution."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is known as the silver ratio and is a Pisot–Vijayaraghavan number, which has the property that higher powers are closer and closer to an integer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For very high powers of a PV number the resultant number will look like either."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n.99999999999999..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"or"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n.00000000000000..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By inspection of the first few powers of the silver ratio we can see that odd powers are slightly above an integer and even powers are slightly below an integer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, since the power is even (3000) the number will look like"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n.9999999999999999..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and the power 3000 is sufficient to make the 9's continue past the 1000th digit of the result - therefore the answer is 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
